bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, July 5 and 29, 1723

div1.p:
Robert Carter writes to Weymouth merchant Edward Tucker, July 5, 1723, to inform him that he has drawn a bill of exchange on him to the London slave traders, Francis Chamberlaye and Francis Sitwell. He reports several other bills, including one from John Wormeley for a cask of Tucker's brandy. He closes by noting that he hopes to send 10-12 hogsheads of tobacco on board Capt. Wilson's ship but has not heard whether there will be room for them on board. In a lengthy post script dated July 29th, Carter notes that Capt. Wilson has been delayed by sickness, and that the weather has reduced the expectations of a good crop. He tells Tucker that the news of a prohibition of importation of stemmed tobacco into England has been confirmed in Virginia, and suggests that Tucker and the other English merchants will need to learn to "Cheat as fast as they [the Scots]," they may be able to survive. He is not sure how long this sad state of affairs will last because most Scots ships have not found cargoes other than tar this year because they arrived so late.
This text was revised April 5, 2002, to include the post script.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to Edward Tucker, July 5 and 29, 1723

opener.dateline:
[Rappahannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
July the 5th. 1723
Mr. Edd: Tucker——

div1.p:
The chief occasion of this is to advise you that
I have this day drawn on you for 116£ 18S: 0d. 1/2 payable to Messuers
Francis Chamberlain and [Francis] Sittwell which I desire you to answer
at time upon my Accot. I have been under a necessity of mak[ing]
use of this money, pay them of the ballance of their Negro [con]
cern, altho I have abundance of money lying out upon that
Accot that I cant command a penny of it—

Herein I send you two small bills of Exchange of
my own drawn upon your self, George Yerby for 6£: 4S: 5d
Kitt Garlinton on Ditto 3£: 13S: 4d.

Herein you have also a bill of Exche. of Mr.
Wormlys payable to your self for 9£ and is for a cask of your
Brandy There I think is 2 Cask behind and one hath been drawn
to fill up the rest, and some I have made use of my self.

Willson they tell me will not get away this month
I have sent him word he shall have 10 or 12 hhds of me but
whether he will have room to take them in I have yet no anwer
finding you are so pestered with Strip Tobbo. these I intend shall
be all Leaf which is the needfull at present from Sir —
div1.closer:
Your humble Servant
Postscript to Mr. Tucker's last Lettr.—
Rappa[hannock] July 29th. 1723
Herein are the Seconds of the above mentioned Bills,
Capt. Wilson meets with some delay by sickness, he reckond to
be out in the Bay a Fortnight ago but is Still at my Storehouse
he hath 10 hhds. from me of Leaf Tobo., The Expectation of
a great Crop shrinks upon us Every day by the Unseasonable=
=ness of the Weather, Your Capt. Will see more of It before he goes,
We have it confirmd to Us. the Scotch have
got a Clause in the Tobo. Law prohibitting Stemd Tobo. wch.
Seems to compleat our Ruin & to give us up Entirly as a prey
to them, this Sort of Tobo. the Scotch did not care to Dip in
It would not answer their designs, If you can find a way
to Cheat us fast as they, You may keep pace with them, but
tis our fate to be tyed down to the whole Duty, & if they can
bring Tobo. into the Nation, & Sell it for less, & yet gett Estates,
our Ruin is inevitable. But surely those things will
not last long, their Ships have but Indifferent luck this
Year, they come in So late, many of them will not get loaded
Some fill with Tarr, I am offerd Freight now for Glasgow
for Six pound I am—
Sir Your Humble. Servt—

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1723 July 4 -1724 June 11, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond. There is a 19th-century copy of the letter in the Minor-Blackford Papers, James Monroe Law Office and Museum, Fredericksburg, Virginia.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. His usual return address, the county, and colony have been added for clarity to this unheaded draft.

[1] Francis Chamberlayne may have been the wealthy grocer of London whose daughter Elizabeth married John Francis Fauquier, an official of the mint and director of the Bank of England, between 1694 and 1702. Carter had in 1720 acted as one of the Virginia agents for these London slave traders in the sale of a cargo of slaves. (http://www.geocities.com/markfreemn/francis_fauquier.html )

[2] John Wormeley (1689-1727), a younger son of Ralph Wormeley (d. 1701) for whom Carter had been a trustee in John's youth. When his older brother, Ralph died in 1714, John inherited all of their father's considerable estate in Middlesex and York counties.
